spanishExample: ¡Siéntate! El problema general es que no siento lo mismo que tú.
englishTranslation: Sit down! The general problem is that I don’t feel the same as you.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)
siento: feel, I feel (Sentir, present, 1st person)
siéntate: sit down (Sentarse imperative) NEEDS WORK

spanishExample: ¡Siéntense! Necesitamos que se sienten pronto.
englishTranslation: (plural) Sit down! We need you to sit down soon.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
necesitamos: need, we need (Necesitar, present, 1st person plural)
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)
siéntense: sit down (Sentarse, plural imperative) NEEDS WORK

spanishExample: ¿Cómo me debería sentir? No sabes lo que siento.
englishTranslation: How should I feel? You don’t know what I feel.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question
sentirse: any use of sentir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to feel)
siento: feel, I feel (Sentir, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Cómo te sentiste ayer? ¿Quieres que nos sentemos contigo?
englishTranslation: How did you feel yesterday? Do you want us to sit with you?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)
sentirse: any use of sentir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to feel)
sentiste: feel, you feel (Sentir, preterite, 2nd person)

spanishExample: ¿Dónde se ha sentado la dama? No la veo.
englishTranslation: Where has the lady sat down? I don’t see her.
vocabIncluded: dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)
veo: see, I see (Ver, present, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¿Dónde te sientas? ¿Y dónde se sienta ella?
englishTranslation: Where are you sitting? And where is she sitting?
vocabIncluded: dónde: adverb meaning "where?" in a question or implied question
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)

spanishExample: ¿Nos sentamos? Ella sentía que querías eso.
englishTranslation: Do we sit down? She felt like you wanted that.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)
sentía: felt, he/she/it felt (Sentir, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¿Podemos sentarnos? ¿Cómo te has estado sintiendo estos días?
englishTranslation: Can we sit? How have you been feeling these days?
vocabIncluded: cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question
has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)
sentirse: any use of sentir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to feel)

spanishExample: ¿Puedes ver la mano izquierda de ese santo?
englishTranslation: Can you see the left hand of that saint?

spanishExample: ¿Quieres sentarte? Y nosotros, ¿podemos sentarnos también?
englishTranslation: Do you want to sit? And we, can we sit too?
vocabIncluded: sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)

spanishExample: ¿Ves lo que hay a la izquierda? Es el diablo.
englishTranslation: Do you see what there is on the left? It’s the devil.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)
ves: see, you see (Ver, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Al muchacho y a la muchacha les gustan esos diablos.
englishTranslation: The teenage boy and teenage girl like those devils.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
al: "to the" before a masculine noun
gustan: like, they like (Gustar, present, 3rd person plural)
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")

spanishExample: El caballero fue derecho por esa calle.
englishTranslation: The gentleman went straight down that street.

spanishExample: Él siente que el caballero fue al lugar correcto.
englishTranslation: He feels like the gentleman went to the right place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
al: "to the" before a masculine noun
siente: feels, he/she/it feels (Sentir, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Estamos sentados donde él se sentó antes.
englishTranslation: We are seated where he sat before.
vocabIncluded: sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)

spanishExample: La muchacha dijo que podía sentarme con ella y hablar de esos demonios.
englishTranslation: The teenage girl said I could sit with her and talk about those demons.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
de used to mean "about", as in "hablar de"
hablar: to speak / to talk (Hablar infinitive)
podía: "was able", "I was able" (Poder, imperfect, 1st person)
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)

spanishExample: Lo siento, pero no queremos que el muchacho se siente aquí.
englishTranslation: I’m sorry, but we don’t want the teenage boy to sit here.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)
siente: sit, he/she/it sit (Sentar, subjunctive, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Me senté y le hablé de mis secretos.
englishTranslation: I sat down and talked to her about my secrets.
vocabIncluded: de used to mean "about", as in "hablar de"
hablé: spoke, I spoke (Hablar, preterite, 1st person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)

spanishExample: No quiero que él se sienta como tú te sientes.
englishTranslation: I don’t want him to feel like you feel.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sentirse: any use of sentir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to feel)
sienta: feel, he/she/it feel (Sentir, subjunctive, 3rd person)
sientes: feel, you feel (Sentir, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: No sé si ese santo era real.
englishTranslation: I don’t know if that saint was real.

spanishExample: No sentí lo que decían sobre él.
englishTranslation: I didn’t feel what they said about him.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
sentí: felt, I felt (Sentir, preterite, 1st person)

spanishExample: Quieres que me sienta mejor porque ellos se sienten mal.
englishTranslation: You want me to feel better because they feel bad.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sentirse: any use of sentir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to feel)
sienta: feel, I feel (Sentir, subjunctive, 1st person)
sienten: feel, they feel (Sentir, present, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Se sentaron cerca de donde nosotros nos sentamos.
englishTranslation: They sat near where we sat.
vocabIncluded: cerca: near (adverb often used with de)
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)

spanishExample: Sentía que estaba mal, pero no quiero que tú sientas lo mismo.
englishTranslation: I felt like it was wrong, but I don’t want you to feel the same.
vocabIncluded: "lo": "the" with no noun, as in "lo bueno"
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sentía: felt, I felt (Sentir, imperfect, 1st person)
sientas: feel, you feel (Sentir, subjunctive, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Sentimos que deberías hablar con Dios de tus futuros problemas.
englishTranslation: We feel like you should talk to God about your future problems.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
de used to mean "about", as in "hablar de"
deberías: should, you should (Deber, conditional, 2nd person)
hablar: to speak / to talk (Hablar infinitive)
sentimos: feel, we feel (Sentir, present, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Sentimos que ellos no quieren que nos sentemos con ellos.
englishTranslation: We felt like they don’t want us to sit with them.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)
sentimos: felt, we felt (Sentir, preterite, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Siempre se sientan donde tú te sentaste.
englishTranslation: They always sit where you sat.
vocabIncluded: sentarse: any use of to sit with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to sit down)

spanishExample: Sientes que la dama va a ir hacia la derecha.
englishTranslation: You feel like the lady is going to go to the right.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
sientes: feel, you feel (Sentir, present, 2nd person)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Siéntese, no se ha sentido bien en las últimas horas.
englishTranslation: (formal) Sit down, you haven’t felt well in the last hours.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
sentirse: any use of sentir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to feel)
siéntese: sit down (Sentarse, formal imperative) NEEDS WORK

spanishExample: Sintieron que no querían hablar de Dios.
englishTranslation: They felt like they didn’t want to talk about God.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
de used to mean "about", as in "hablar de"
hablar: to speak / to talk (Hablar infinitive)
sintieron: felt, they felt (Sentir, preterite, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Sintió que había muchos demonios.
englishTranslation: He felt like there were many demons.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)
sintió: felt, he/she/it felt (Sentir, preterite, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Tengo un problema en mi mano derecha y no me siento bien.
englishTranslation: I have a problem in my right hand and I don’t feel well.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
sentirse: any use of sentir with a reflexive pronoun, changing the meaning to feel)
siento: sit, I sit (Sentar, present, 1st person)
